description: From Middle English consonant or consonaunt, from Old French consonant, from Latin cōnsonāns (“sounding with”), from the prefix con- (“with”) + the present participle sonāns (“sounding”), from sonāre (“to sound”). The Latin is a calque of Ancient Greek σύμφωνον (súmphōnon).

adjectives.description: consonant (comparative more consonant, superlative most consonant)

entries.meaning: consistent, harmonious, compatible, or in agreement
examples: Each one pretends that his opinion  […]  is consonant to the words there used.

entries.meaning: Of or relating to consonants; made up of, or containing many, consonants.
examples: No Russian whose dissonant consonant name / Almost shatters to fragments the trumpet of fame.

entries.meaning: (phonetics) A sound that results from the passage of air through restrictions of the oral cavity; any sound that is not the dominant sound of a syllable, the dominant sound generally being a vowel.
A letter representing the sound of a consonant.
examples: The 20 unquestionable consonants in the English alphabet are B, C, D, F, G, H, J, K, L, M, N, P, Q, R, S, T, V, W,
